figure_1.title: Figure 1:
figure_1.caption: Overview of Wastewater-based Epidemiology Surveillance System.

figure_3.title: Figure 3:
figure_3.caption: The guidance of sampling method selection. Each column represents a condition to be considered and each box indicates which sampling method we should choose under given circumstances.

figure_4.title: Figure 4:
figure_4.caption: The overview of wastewater data analytics.

figure_5.title: Figure 5:
figure_5.caption: The SEIR model and extended SEIR model used in the current literature.

figure_6.title: Figure 6:
figure_6.caption: The uncertainty of wastewater-based COVID-19 surveillance.

figure_7.title: Figure 7:
figure_7.caption: Current Viral Activity Levels Given by CDC (2024a)

claims.sentence: Figure 1 shows the overview of the wastewater-based epidemic surveillance system.

Figure 1:

Open in a new tab
Overview of Wastewater-based Epidemiology Surveillance System.While a promising tool, wastewater-based COVID-19 surveillance and beyond is subject to some key limitations and challenges.
The detailed process and outcome are shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2:

Open in a new tab
Publication selection process: PRISMA-based flowchart.3.
Moreover, according to the literature we reviewed, we provide a sampling method selection guideline by considering different factors in real applications as shown in Figure 3.
The organization of this section is illustrated in Figure 4.

Figure 4:

Open in a new tab
The overview of wastewater data analytics.5.1.

Specifically, the framework assumes that the spread of COVID-19 follows the SEIR model and that the viral load in wastewater is solely contributed by the infected population as illustrated in the left panel of Figure 5.

Figure 5:

Open in a new tab
The SEIR model and extended SEIR model used in the current literature.Directly inferring the SEIR model from the viral load in wastewater may yield unstable results due to noisy viral fluctuations.
To address this issue, Nourbakhsh el al. presented an extended SEIR model as illustrated in the right panel of Figure 5 (Nourbakhsh et al., 2022).
In Figure 6, we summarize the possible uncertainties introduced in each key steps of the WBE system.

Figure 6:

Open in a new tab
The uncertainty of wastewater-based COVID-19 surveillance.Li et al. (2021b) systematically studied the uncertainty in estimating SARS-CoV-2 prevalence by WBE.

The NWSS is implemented in all 50 states, 3 territories, and 5 tribal organizations as shown in Figure 7, which provides early detection of changes in disease trends before trends are seen in clinical cases.

Figure 7:

Open in a new tab
Current Viral Activity Levels Given by CDC (2024a)In addition to COVID-19, the CDC also uses the NWSS to monitor the Mpox and Influenza A as shown in Figure8 and Figure9 (CDC, 2024c).

Figure 8:

Open in a new tab
Mpox Virus Detection in Wastewater (CDC, 2024d)Figure 9:

Open in a new tab
Wastewater Data for Influenza A (CDC, 2024b)According to the working experience of the CDC, wastewater surveillance data are most useful when used with other data, such as overall levels of the virus in wastewater, historical wastewater data for that location, geographical context, and clinical cases.
